title: 114_hr5245
content: The Act is titled the "Better Oversight of Secondary Sales and Accountability in Concert Ticketing Act of 2016". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act provides definitions for terms such as ancillary charges, base price, box office, bundled series tickets, and distribution method related to ticket sales. The term "face value" refers to the total price of a ticket, including the base price and any additional charges. "Primary sale" means the initial sale of a ticket to the general public by a primary ticket seller. The term "primary ticket seller" includes owners or operators of venues, sports teams, event managers, or ticketing service providers who engage in the primary sale of tickets. The terms "resale" or "secondary sale" refer to any ticket sale after the initial sale. A "secondary ticket sales marketplace" is a platform for reselling tickets. A "ticket" is an admission pass to events or amusements. SEC. 3. RULES ON TRANSPARENCY OF TICKET MARKETING, DISTRIBUTION, AND PRICING BY PRIMARY TICKET SELLERS. The Federal Trade Commission must establish rules within 180 days of this Act for primary ticket sellers to disclose the total number of tickets available for sale and distribution methods not less than 7 days before tickets are available for sale. The Act requires primary ticket sellers to disclose distribution methods, sale dates, ticket prices with all charges included, and refund policies with ancillary charges. The Act prohibits primary ticket sellers from dictating how consumers can resell tickets and mandates a full refund for nontransferable tickets if requested at least 1 week before the event. SEC. 4. RULES FOR SECONDARY TICKET SALES MARKETPLACES. The Federal Trade Commission must create rules within 180 days of this Act for secondary ticket sales, including requirements for clear disclosure if the marketplace does not possess the ticket at the time of sale and procedures for obtaining a refund if the ticket received does not match the description. The Act mandates rules for secondary ticket sales, including disclosure requirements for marketplaces, prohibition on software circumvention of security measures, and sale of tickets obtained in violation. Additionally, resale marketplaces must disclose ticket details like distribution method, face value, and seat location. The Act mandates rules for secondary ticket sales, including disclosure requirements for marketplaces. Resale marketplaces must disclose ticket details like distribution method, face value, and seat location. Online resale marketplaces are required not to make any representation of affiliation without consent. The Act prohibits individuals involved in ticket sales from reselling tickets at a higher price than face value. It also requires online resale marketplaces to provide clear notice of their purpose for secondary ticket sales. The Act prohibits reselling tickets above face value or to third parties intending to do so. Online resale marketplaces must disclose if they are associated with the primary ticket seller, venue, team, or artist. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Federal Trade Commission and State Attorneys General have the authority to enforce violations of rules and practices that are deemed unfair or deceptive. State Attorneys General can take action if the residents of their state are affected by such violations. The State, as parens patriae, may bring a civil action on behalf of residents to enjoin, enforce compliance, obtain damages, and seek other relief for violations of rules. Notice must be served to the Commission at least 60 days prior to initiating the civil action. The State can bring a civil action on behalf of residents to enforce compliance with rules, with notice required to be served to the Commission at least 60 days prior. The State may provide a copy of the complaint to the Commission, and the FTC may intervene in the civil action, be heard on all matters, remove the action to the appropriate court, and file petitions for appeal. The attorney general of a State can still exercise powers conferred by state laws. The attorney general of a State can exercise powers conferred by state laws to conduct investigations, administer oaths, compel witnesses, and produce evidence. In a civil action, the venue shall be where the defendant is found, an inhabitant, transacts business, or where venue is proper under section 1391 of title 28, United States Code. In civil actions, process can be served without territorial limits, and a person involved in an alleged violation can be joined in the action regardless of residence. The FTC can preempt state actions during its own proceedings for rule violations. Private Right of Action allows individuals who suffer injury from a violation of rules to bring civil action in a US district court, seeking damages and attorney fees. If a State prevails in a civil action, they can recover costs and fees from the lender or related party. SEC. 6. NONPREEMPTION. This Act does not override State or local laws on ticket resale regulation unless they conflict with this Act or provide less consumer protection. SEC. 7. FTC STUDY OF TICKET MARKET. The Federal Trade Commission will conduct a study on the ticket market, focusing on who buys tickets from primary sellers, the impact of nontransferable tickets on consumers, and the use of automated ticket-purchasing programs. A report will be submitted to Congress within a year of the Act's enactment.
